text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are no longer benefiting but the idea is that I want to go to chemotherapy on its own or as part of the study vis a vis switching to this. Patient: How long would the chemotherapy? How long would that last? Doctor: Okay, so the chemotherapy, we tend to give ten cycles if it’s benefiting you. They’re given once every three weeks. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Or if it’s not benefiting you, we usually know by the third or fourth cycle that your PSA is rising and you don’t tolerate it so we have to make some changes. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? So when the numbers change, it’s consent forms. Patient: Yeah, yeah, put that right Doctor: So that’s your homework. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay, and then I will send Dr. G an email tomorrow and make sure he sees what I’m thinking,

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: We may have at the start of this study. Uh, uh, and it can change with therapy. So, you would have to repeat it again. Um, and you’ve had Enzalutamide, so I think you’d be good to go on that one. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh, that you actually would stay on the Enzalutamide and if you’re AR-V7 positive, well then we have, uh, some of the new list of new therapies that are being used in other tumor types. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And, then, we’re looking to see what they’re likelihood of benefiting men with prostate cancer are. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have done a handful of men before, and the handful of men seemed to have their PSA drop for awhile. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But, it’s not the mega excitement in prostate cancer, uh, that we see with the other tumors that you hear on the news with Jimmy Carter and all of those kinds of – Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Um, it can possibly benefit people for awhile.

text: Patient: That’s a different study. Doctor: Because that only works against the bone. Patient: Oh. Doctor: So unless I see and okay the bone scan, I was just looking, they did they compared it to a two-thousand-fourteen bone scan. So I really cannot tell too much. The only new findings are really this one on your bone scan – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: and that we are very well aware about that we know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So those were there even before you started the Xofigo. Patient: Right. Doctor: The radiation. Patient: Right. Doctor: So right now I think we will be in just watch and wait mode because I see no recompelling reason to put you on a new treatment.

text: Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, and is that just a swollen gland from inflammation that’s coming there. Cancer really shouldn’t give you a gland. You know, unless that gland is involved. text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
